instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used for mapping pan-European land cover and land use?
Output: Per-pixel spectral-temporal metrics were computed from six reﬂectance bands and six vegetation indices for classifying land cover.

instruction: What metric was chosen for mapping pan-European land cover and land use and how far can this metric go?
Output: In the study, the metric chosen was spectral-temporal metrics. This metric was used to capture seasonal variations of land surface spectra and reduce the impact of clouds and cloud-shadows. It provided an efficient means to map pan-European land cover and land use by relaxing the limitations imposed by image-based classification methods. The study found that using this metric, the best classification model based on Landsat-8 data from three years achieved an accuracy of 75.1%, which was nearly 2 percentage points higher than the model based on a single year of Landsat data. This suggests that the spectral-temporal metrics can go a long way in mapping pan-European land cover and land use, but temporally dynamic classes may still benefit from more frequent satellite observations.

instruction: How did the study assess the potential of combining the LUCAS land survey and Landsat-8 data for mapping pan-European land cover and land use?
Output: The study assessed the potential of combining the LUCAS land survey and Landsat-8 data for mapping pan-European land cover and land use by using annual and seasonal spectral-temporal metrics and environmental features. These metrics allowed for capturing seasonal variations of land surface spectra and reducing the impact of clouds and cloud-shadows. The study compared the classification models based on Landsat-8 data from three years (2014-2016) and a single year (2015) to determine the best model. The accuracy of the classification model based on three years of data was found to be 75.1%, which was nearly 2 percentage points higher than the model based on a single year of data. The study concluded that annual pan-European land cover maps are feasible, but certain classes like artificial land, cropland, and grassland benefit from more frequent satellite observations.

instruction: How does combining the LUCAS land survey and Landsat-8 data improve the accuracy of pan-European land cover mapping compared to traditional methods?
Output:
Combining the LUCAS land survey and Landsat-8 data improves the accuracy of pan-European land cover mapping compared to traditional methods by utilizing spectral-temporal metrics and environmental features. This approach allows for the capture of seasonal variations in land surface spectra and reduces the impact of clouds and cloud-shadows, which are limitations in image-based classification methods. 

The study found that the best classification model, based on three years of Landsat-8 data (2014-2016), achieved an accuracy of 75.1%. This accuracy was nearly 2 percentage points higher than the classification model based on a single year of Landsat data (2015). 

Furthermore, the study showed that the produced pan-European land cover map compared favorably to the existing CORINE 2012 land cover dataset. The mapped country-wide area proportions strongly correlated with LUCAS-estimated area proportions, indicating the reliability of the combined approach. 

Overall, the combination of the LUCAS land survey and Landsat-8 data, along with the use of spectral-temporal metrics and environmental features, improves the accuracy of pan-European land cover mapping by providing more detailed and up-to-date information compared to traditional methods.
